title: Pendle Paid £17K to Marston Holdings While Company Filed Dormant Accounts
author: AI DOGE Investigation
excerpt: Pendle Borough Council paid £17,100 to Marston (Holdings) Ltd during a period when the company had filed dormant accounts with Companies House — a contradiction that suggests either fraudulent accounts or illegitimate payments.

blocks.title: Dormant Company Received Active Payments
blocks.subtitle: Marston Holdings declared no transactions while receiving £17K from Pendle Council

items: Received £17,100 from Pendle during this period
Part of £37,800 total breach payments (lowest of 3 councils)

blocks.heading: The Dormant Accounts Contradiction
blocks.content: When a company files dormant accounts, it's declaring to Companies House that it had no significant accounting transactions during the period. Yet Marston (Holdings) Ltd received £17,100 from Pendle Council. This creates a direct contradiction: either the accounts were fraudulent, or the payments weren't legitimate business transactions.

blocks.heading: Pendle's Lower Breach Total
blocks.content: While Pendle still has governance failures, the scale is notably smaller than Burnley and Hyndburn: just £37,800 total paid to 4 breach suppliers versus Burnley's £223,900 (21 suppliers) and Hyndburn's £1.1 million (17 suppliers). This suggests either better due diligence or less complex supplier relationships.

blocks.heading: Jewson Ltd: The Second Breach
blocks.content: Jewson Ltd, a well-known builders merchant, also received £17,000 from Pendle while filing dormant accounts. Unlike Marston Holdings, Jewson is a major national company, making this breach particularly surprising — large companies should have robust compliance processes. This may indicate a data timing issue or a subsidiary/parent company confusion rather than deliberate fraud.

blocks.heading: Relative Performance
blocks.content: Pendle emerges from this analysis with the cleanest supplier compliance record of the three East Lancashire councils. However, even £37,800 in breach payments represents public money paid to companies not meeting basic legal requirements. There's still room for improvement in due diligence processes.

blocks.heading: Verify the Claims
blocks.text: Check the payment dates for Marston Holdings against their Companies House filings to see the exact overlap period.
